In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Promoting good governance—i.e., capacity building and state strengthening—is central 
to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) country strategy and program (CSP), 2005–20091 for 
Nepal as well as to the new country partnership strategy, (CPS), 2010–2012. These strategies 
recognize that inclusive and effective public service delivery is essential for reducing poverty 
and addressing the root causes of the conflict. They are in line with the government's policies 
and  priorities  as  both  aim  to  support  the  government's  decentralization  initiatives  by 
strengthening  the  planning  and  implementation  capacity  of  central  and  local  institutions, 
promoting the devolution of service delivery to the local level, and supporting capacity building. 
During the country program confirmation mission in 2008, the government requested technical 
assistance (TA) for capacity development support to the National Planning Commission (NPC) 
to be included in the 2009 program. The TA would support the preparation of a development 
planning framework for a federal system of governance, which Nepal is expected to adopt in the 
near future. ADB undertook a fact-finding mission on 22–24 September 2009 to design the TA. 
The mission reached an understanding with the government on the TA's objectives, scope, 
costs and financing plan, implementation arrangements, and counterpart support. The design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Despite more than 5 decades of planned development, Nepal's development progress 
has  been  much  slower  than  anticipated,  raising  concerns  about  the  effectiveness  of  the 
country's development planning system and institutions. Nepal's planning system needs to be 
made more responsive to the country's development aspirations. The NPC, chaired by the 
prime minister, guides the planning system at the central level. It has three interrelated functions: 
(i) advising the government on socioeconomic development, (ii) coordinating the formulation of 
periodic  and  annual  plans  and  programs,  and  (iii)  monitoring  and  evaluating  development 
activities in general and implementation of the government's priority plans and programs in 
particular.  
 
3.  There are, however, widespread concerns about the weak institutional capacity of the 
NPC to perform these functions effectively. There are weaknesses in the policy formulation 
process,  a  lack  of  a  long-term  policy  perspective  in  planning,  and  limitations  in  the 
implementation of the monitoring and evaluation system, resulting in limited feedback into the 
implementation and policy and program formulation process. The links between planning and 
monitoring and evaluation activities at the central and local levels are weak, in part because of 
the lack of a proper database or computerized networking. As a result, the overall development 
process is driven from the top and lacks inclusiveness.  
 
4.  With the country on the threshold of a historic political transition, development planning 
is at a crossroads. The first session of the Constituent Assembly elected in April 2008 declared 
its intention to move from a unitary structure of governance to a federal system. The Constituent 
Assembly is in the process of drafting a new constitution along federal lines, which it expects to 
complete by May 2010. The introduction of a federal system of governance will have direct and 
far-reaching implications for Nepal's economic and development planning, which has so far 
been focused at the national level. In particular, the planning system will need to be reframed

and the role and functions of NPC will need to be redefined vis-à-vis the planning agencies at 
the level of federal units. 
 
5.  Although the type of federal structure is still being deliberated as part of the ongoing 
constitution drafting process, the structure is unlikely to differ significantly from those of other 
federal  countries  in  the  region.  Considering  the  far-reaching  implications  of  the  political 
transition and the weak institutional capacity in the government, it will be important to carefully 
examine different options of development planning, to ensure adoption of a suitable planning 
system in Nepal. This will facilitate well-informed decision making during the drafting of the new 
constitution and the subsequent restructuring of the development planning framework.  
 
6.  The government has embarked on a process to prepare a new periodic plan to succeed 
the current Three-Year Interim Plan, which will conclude in mid-July 2010. Given the expected 
transition to a federal system of governance and development planning, the new periodic plan 
will need to begin the process of transition by reorienting the planning process and focusing 
more on decentralization and inclusive approaches to planning and programming. The NPC 
needs  to  be  strengthened  and  reoriented  toward  results-based  planning  and  monitoring 
approaches  to  respond  to  the  high  public  expectations  of  tangible  development  benefits. 
Strengthening the government's planning, implementation, and monitoring systems will facilitate 
effective implementation of ADB's CPS, 2010–2012 and any mid-course adjustments that are 
needed to align with the government's plans and priorities. 
 
7.  Adoption of a new planning framework will entail revamping and reorienting the role and 
functions of the NPC and possibly other related public institutions, which will in turn require 
institutional,  organizational  and  legal  restructuring.  The  government  needs  technical  and 
advisory support to explore the different options of a federal system of development planning. It 
needs to identify a suitable model for Nepal, redefine the roles and responsibilities of the NPC 
and other public institutions, develop a framework for institutional and legal restructuring, and 
devise a strategy for the transition. The government also needs assistance to re-orient the new 
periodic plan toward more decentralized and inclusive approaches. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The impact of the TA will be institutionalization of a federal system of development 
planning suitable to Nepal's context. The TA will help the Government to examine different 
options of development planning in a federal system of governance and the implications for 
Nepal. This will in turn help to take a well-informed policy decision on the form and substance of 
a development planning system suitable to Nepal, thereby facilitating its institutionalization, 
including restructuring of the government's central planning organization (NPC).   
 
9.  The outcome of the TA will be strengthened institutional capacity of the government for 
decision  making  on  the  establishment  of  a  federal  system  of  development  planning  and 
restructuring the NPC. The TA outputs (described below) and the government's participation in 
developing these will help to understand the implications of various development planning 
modalities, facilitating a rational decision making process. 
 
10.  The key outputs of the TA will be (i) a development planning framework suitable for the 
federal system Nepal is expected to adopt, based on an analysis of different options; (ii) a new 
and detailed organizational structure for the proposed planning institution at the central level,

3
(iii) a broad organizational structure for planning institutions, if any, at the state and local levels 
and a description of their relation with the central planning body, (iv) a strategy and a road map 
for making a transition to the new planning process, and (v) inputs for formulating the key 
components of the new periodic plan (infrastructure and social development) and orienting the 
plan toward more decentralized, inclusive and results-based approaches as part of the transition 
to a federal system of planning. 
  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The proposed TA will have two components. Component A will support the development 
of a new planning framework under a federal system of governance. Component B will support 
the formulation of  a transitional periodic plan.  
 
12.  Component  A  will  be  based  on  a  thorough  review  and  assessment  of  the  current 
situation in Nepal, international best practices, and prospects for change in view of the current 
political transition. Activities will consist of a comprehensive review of all aspects of Nepal's 
existing  development  planning  system,  including  its  processes,  institutions,  and  legal 
frameworks  at  all  levels.  Extensive  reviews  and  consultations  will  be  undertaken  with 
stakeholders to gain an understanding of the status of the constitution drafting process and the 
form and substance of the form of federalism that is likely to be adopted in the new constitution.  
Documents will be reviewed and a comparative analysis will be carried out of different models of 
federal  system  of  development  planning  in  other  countries.  Observation  visits  to  suitable 
countries with federal system of planning will be organized for relevant government officials and 
policy  makers  for  them  to  better  understand  federal  system  of  planning  in  practice  and 
internalize  the  experience  of  other  countries.  This  will  contribute  to  conceptualizing  an 
appropriate planning system for Nepal.  
 
13.  Component A will review previous studies supported by ADB and other organizations on 
such  topics  as  fiscal  federalism,  the  formulation  of  regional  development  strategies,  and 
economic policy networking. Based on these reviews and consultations through workshops, 
seminars and meetings, the TA will propose a development planning framework for the central, 
state  and  local  levels  suitable  to  Nepal's  context.  The  proposed  development  planning 
framework  will  be  presented  to  a  wide  range  of  stakeholders  in  brainstorming  sessions, 
workshops, and seminars to build country ownership and ensure responsiveness and relevance 
to Nepal's context and needs. As the proposed planning framework will have legal ramifications, 
the TA will analyze the existing legal framework and propose any new legal provisions that will 
need  to  be  made,  including  provisions  in  the  constitution,  formulation  of  a  new  act,  and 
amendments to the existing legal provisions.  
 
14.  Based on the proposed development planning framework, the TA will develop a detailed 
organizational structure so the central planning agency can perform the key functions identified 
in the proposed planning framework. The organizational structure will include overall size and 
structure,  functional  units  and  their  terms  of  reference,  reporting  systems  with  a  proper 
database and computerized networking, human resource requirements, development plans, and 
relations with other central, state and local institutions. Broad organizational structures will also 
be developed for the planning bodies, if any, at state and local levels. 
 
15.  To  help  implement  the  proposed  development  planning  framework  and  institutional 
structure, the TA will develop a strategy and a road map to facilitate and guide the transition to 
the new planning process. The road map will be prepared in close consultation with relevant 
government agencies and other stakeholders.

4   
 
16.  Component B  will review the government's past and current periodic plans, particularly 
the Tenth Plan, the Three-Year Interim Plan and the draft national development strategy, the 
finalization of which was disrupted by political changes. It will also study the process through 
which these plans were formulated, and the preparations for formulating a new periodic plan. 
Based on these reviews and consultations, the TA will support the development of the strategic 
thrusts and sector strategies and plans for the development of key infrastructure and social 
sectors. The TA will also provide specific strategic inputs to orient the new periodic plan toward 
more decentralized and inclusive approaches. The inputs of component B are urgently needed 
by the government as the new periodic plan needs to be finalized by mid-July 2010. Early 
initiation of component B activities will also provide a useful basis for developing the new 
development planning framework under the component A.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $740,000 equivalent. ADB will provide $625,000 on a grant 
basis from its Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The main elements to be funded 
by ADB are the services of international and national consultants, equipment, and workshops 
and  seminars.  The  government  will  contribute  $115,000  equivalent  to  provide  office 
accommodation,  counterpart  staff  support,  facilities  for  seminars  and  meetings,  and  other 
administrative expenses. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  Institutional arrangements. The NPC will be the executing and implementing agency 
for both TA components. Both components will be implemented in close coordination with other 
government  agencies,  including  the  Ministry  of  Finance  and  other  line  ministries  and 
departments. A TA project coordination committee (PCC) will be established for component A 
within the NPC, headed by the secretary of the NPC secretariat. The PCC head, supported by 
other  PCC  members  represented  by  NPC  staff  and  other  government  agencies  and  the 
consultants under component A, will supervise and manage day-to-day TA activities. The PCC 
will be supervised and guided by a project steering committee, chaired by the NPC vice chair. 
The committee will consist of other concerned NPC officials, representatives from relevant 
ministries, local governments, civil society, and experts. The steering committee will provide 
overall policy and strategic guidance and interagency coordination for TA activities, monitor 
progress and take necessary actions to facilitate TA implementation.   
 
19.  Individual  consultants  under  component  B  will  work  closely  with  the  technical 
committees  (chaired  by  the  concerned  joint  secretaries  of  the  NPC  and  comprising 
representatives of line ministries and other technical experts), which NPC will constitute for 
formulation of the new periodic plan. The technical committees will be supervised and guided by 
a separate steering committee which NPC will constitute, chaired by the concerned member of 
the NPC and comprising other members of the NPC3 and representatives of line ministries 
concerned, to oversee the formulation of the new periodic plan.   
 
20.  Consulting  services.  A  total  of  12  person-months  of  international  and  16  person- 
months of national consulting services will be provided under the TA. An international consultant 
firm will be selected in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as

amended from time to time) for component A. The consultant firm will be selected using the 
quality- and cost-based selection method, the type of proposal will be a bio-data technical 
proposal, and the weighting of the technical and financial proposals will be 80:20.The consultant 
team will comprise three international consultants (a federal development planning specialist, a 
fiscal decentralization specialist, and an institutional and organizational development specialist) 
and  three  national  consultants  (a  decentralization  specialist,  a  legal  and  an  institutional 
specialist, and an organizational development specialist). Outline terms of reference for the 
consultant services are in Appendix 3. Three national consultants (an infrastructure specialist, 
and social and inclusive development specialists) will be engaged for component B. They will 
be selected on an individual basis, also in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants. Outline terms of reference for them are provided in Appendix 3. Equipment will be 
procured by the component A consultant firm in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2007, as amended from time to time), and will be handed over to the government upon 
completion of the TA. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB's 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.4 
 
21.  The team leader under component A of the TA will submit an inception report including a 
detailed work program for the TA to the PCC and ADB within 30 days of commencement of 
component A activities. Quarterly progress reports and mid-term reports will also be submitted. 
A draft final report will be submitted 1 month prior to completion of the TA activities, and a final 
report,  incorporating  comments  of  the  executing  agency  (EA)  and  ADB,  3  weeks  after 
completion of the TA. 
 
22.  For component B, the individual consultants will submit their inception reports separately 
to their respective technical committees and ADB within 30 days of commencement of their 
assignments. They will also submit draft final reports two weeks prior to the completion of their 
assignments and final reports, incorporating the EA's and ADB's comments, two weeks after 
completion of their assignments.  
 
23.  The TA will be implemented over a period of 14 calendar months, starting from early 
December 2009 for component B and March 2010 for component A. The component A steering 
committee will meet for the inception of the TA and at least every 3 months thereafter to review 
implementation progress and address any implementation issues. It will guide the TA team in 
the  event  of  any  unforeseen  political  developments  affecting  implementation.  The  steering 
committee  for  component  B  will  meet  as  frequently  as  deemed  necessary  by  NPC.  The 
component  A  steering  committee  may  invite  representatives  of  civil  society  and  other 
stakeholders to contribute to the TA. ADB will field regular missions to review implementation 
progress, and particularly to guide the TA consultants (in consultation with the EA). These 
missions will make appropriate recommendations to the EA and ADB management should the 
implementation environment change drastically, affecting the achievement of the TA objectives. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
24  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $625,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Nepal for Institutional Strengthening of the National Planning Commission, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Component  
 
1.  Federal Development Planning Specialist and Team Leader (international, 6 person-
months)  
 
a.  Basic Qualifications 
 
(i)  A master's degree in social sciences. 
(ii)  International work experience relevant to the tasks described below. 
(iii)  Relevant work experience, preferably in Nepal or other South Asian countries. 
(iv)  At least 10 years' overall work experience. 
 
b.  Tasks to be Performed 
 
(i)  As a team leader of component A, supervise and coordinate the work of other 
component A consultants, ensure quality and timely outputs and deliverables and 
submission  to  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  of  relevant  documents  as 
specified in the consultant contract. Apart from the initial mobilization advance, all 
subsequent payments will be subject to delivery of specific outputs and draft reports 
(to be determined during contract negotiations). In particular, the final payment will 
be made only upon delivery of the final report and other relevant outputs to the 
satisfaction of ADB and the executing agency (EA).  
(ii)  Establish rapport and coordinate with relevant government institutions and other 
stakeholders to build consensus and awareness on the TA objectives. 
(iii)  Conduct and manage meetings, workshops and seminars for consultations as part 
of  the  TA  activities  as  appropriate  and  requested  by  component  A  steering 
committee, ADB, and other stakeholders. 
(iv)  In consultation with the steering committee and ADB, organize an observation visit 
for relevant government officials and other policy makers to suitable countries with 
federal system of development planning. 
(v)  Review  the  current  system  of  development  planning  in  Nepal  and  conduct  a 
comprehensive and participatory assessment of the current structure, functions and 
performance of National Planning Commission (NPC), involving a wide range of 
stakeholders. 
(vi)  With the support of other team members, review the status of the drafting of the new 
constitution and undertake wide consultations to assess the federal structure being 
contemplated. 
(vii)  Review  best  international  practice  and  present  different  options  for  the  federal 
system of development planning, with an analysis of their relevance, effectiveness 
and responsiveness to Nepal's needs. 
(viii)  Based on these options and an assessment of the likely federal structure to be 
adopted, develop, through constant consultations with key stakeholders, a suitable 
development planning framework for Nepal, encompassing the different tiers of 
government; central, state and local. 
(ix)  Based on the proposed framework and with the support of other team members, 
develop  an  appropriate  institutional  framework  for  carrying  out  the  proposed 
development planning system.

(x)  With the support of other TA team members, develop an appropriate organizational 
structure for the central planning agency, including its roles, responsibilities, human 
resource development, and business plan. 
(xi)  Prepare a strategy and a road map for making a transition from the current system 
of development planning to the proposed federal system of planning. 
(xii)  The  team  leader  will  be  responsible  for  submitting  timely  and  quality  progress 
reports as follows: (a) an inception report, including a detailed work program for 
component A to the project coordination committee and ADB within 30 days of 
commencement of the assignment;  (b) quarterly progress reports and midterm 
reports; (c) a draft final report 1 month prior to completion of component A activities; 
and (d) a final report, incorporating the EA's and ADB's comments 3 weeks after 
completion of the assignment. 
 
2.  Fiscal Decentralization Specialist   (international,  3 person-months) 
 
a.  Basic Qualifications 
 
(i)  A master's degree in economics and/or public finance. 
(ii)  International work experience relevant to the tasks described below. 
(iii)  Relevant work experience, preferably in Nepal or other South Asian countries. 
(iv)  At least 10 years' overall work experience. 
 
b.  Tasks to be Performed 
 
(i)  Review earlier studies conducted with support from ADB or other institutions on 
fiscal federalism in Nepal. 
(ii)  Under  the  guidance  of  the  team  leader,  analyze  fiscal  decentralization,  fiscal 
management and planning, and intergovernment transfers  in the federal system of 
development planning 
(iii)  Organize and lead stakeholder consultations (workshops, seminars and informal 
brainstorming  sessions)  to  obtain  feedback  to  be  used  to  define  the  role  and 
functions of the proposed central planning agency in fiscal decentralization. 
(iv)  Define the role and responsibilities of the restructured central planning agency in 
fiscal  decentralization  and  management  in  the  federal  system  of  development 
planning. 
(v)  Submit reports on inputs to the team leader as required, supporting the delivery of 
the overall component A reports to the EA and ADB. 
 
3.  Institutional and Organizational Development Specialist (international, 3 person-
months) 
 
a.  Basic Qualifications 
 
(i)  A master's degree in management and/or public administration 
(ii)  International work experience relevant to the tasks described below. 
(iii)  Relevant work experience, preferably in Nepal or other South Asian countries. 
(iv)  At least 10 years' overall work experience.

Appendix 3   11
     
b.  Tasks to be Performed 
 
(i)  Review the current institutional arrangements for development planning in Nepal 
and the organizational structure of the NPC and its role in development planning 
and policy analysis. 
(ii)  Organize and lead stakeholder consultations (workshops, seminars and informal 
brainstorming sessions as necessary) to obtain feedback to be used to develop 
institutional and organizational frameworks for carrying out the proposed federal 
system of development planning.  
(iii)  Based on the proposed framework for federal system of development planning, 
develop an institutional framework for carrying it out, showing links between and the 
roles of government ministries and other relevant public entities.  
(iv)  Given  this  framework,  develop  an  organizational  structure  for  the  new  central 
planning  agency,  including  its  roles  and  responsibilities,  human  resource 
requirements, financing, business plan, and operational strategy.  
(v)  Submit reports on inputs to the team leader as required, supporting the delivery of 
the overall component A reports to the EA and ADB. 
 
4.  Decentralization Specialist (national, 3 person-months) 
 
a.  Basic Qualifications 
 
(i)  A master's degree in social sciences 
(ii)  Work experience relevant to the tasks described below, preferably in other countries 
besides Nepal.  
(iii)  At least 10 years' overall work experience. 
 
b.  Tasks to be Performed 
 
(i)  Provide the team leader with support and assist him or her by providing knowledge 
on local conditions for carrying out the TA activities.  
(ii)  Review the current institutional, legal and policy framework and the status of and 
concerns about decentralization in the country. 
(iii)  Working closely with the team leader, propose a federal system of development 
planning based on the existing framework, and the likely form and substance of the 
federal system of governance and best international practices.  
(iv)  Submit reports on inputs to the team leader as required, supporting the delivery of 
the overall component A reports to the EA and ADB. 
 
5.  Constitutional and Legal Specialist (national, 1 person-month) 
 
a.  Basic Qualifications 
 
(i)  A law graduate. 
(ii)  Work experience relevant to the tasks described below, preferably in other countries 
besides Nepal.  
(iii)  At least 10 years' overall work experience. 
 
b.  Tasks to be Performed

12   Appendix 3   
 
(i)  Provide the team leader with support and assist him or her by providing knowledge 
about local conditions for carrying out the TA activities.  
(ii)  Review  the  prevailing  legal  framework  and  provisions  and  analyze  the  legal 
ramifications of the proposed federal system of development planning.  
(iii)  Develop an outline of an appropriate legal framework with key elements for carrying 
out the proposed federal system of development planning. 
(iv)  Review the prevailing legal framework within which NPC is currently functioning and 
develop a new legal framework for the restructured central planning agency.  
(v)  Submit reports on inputs to the team leader as required, supporting the delivery of 
the overall component A reports to the EA and ADB. 
 
6.  Institutional and Organizational Development Specialist (national, 3 person-months) 
 
a.  Basic Qualifications 
 
(i)  A master's degree in management and/or public administration 
(ii)  Work experience relevant to the tasks described below, preferably in other countries 
besides Nepal.  
(iii)  At least 10 years' overall work experience. 
 
b.  Tasks to be Performed 
 
(i)  Provide the international institutional and organizational development specialist with 
support and assist him or her by providing knowledge of local conditions for carrying 
out the TA activities.  
(ii)  Working closely with the international institutional and organization development 
specialist, analyze the institutional and organizational implications of the proposed 
federal system of development planning and restructuring of the NPC. 
(iii)  Working closely with the international institutional and organization development 
specialist, develop an institutional framework for the proposed federal system of 
development planning and organizational structure for restructuring the NPC. 
(iv)  Submit reports on inputs to the team leader as required, supporting the delivery of 
the overall component A reports to the EA and ADB. 
 
 
B.  Component  
 
1.  Infrastructure Development Expert (national, 3 person-months) 
 
a.  Basic Qualifications 
 
(i)  A master's degree in engineering 
(ii)  Work experience relevant to the tasks described below, preferably in other countries 
besides Nepal.  
(iii)  At least 10 years' overall work experience. 
 
b.  Tasks to be Performed 
 
(i)  Work closely with the technical committee constituted by NPC for formulating the 
infrastructure development (e.g., power, transport, and irrigation) component of the 
proposed periodic plan, and engage in the plan preparation process.

Appendix 3   13
     
(ii)  Work in accordance with the guidance and direction of the steering committee 
formed in the NPC to formulate the periodic plan. 
(iii)  Under the guidance of the infrastructure development technical committee and in 
collaboration with other infrastructure sector experts engaged by the NPC (who will 
also  be  supervised  by  the  technical  committee),  assess  the  progress  of 
infrastructure development vis-à-vis that envisaged in Three-Year Interim Plan. 
(iv)  Coordinate and undertake activities as required for wide stakeholder consultations, 
including civil society, political leaders, the private sector, and development partners. 
(v)  Facilitate preparatory work and workshops for the formulation of the periodic plan. 
(vi)  Provide  the  necessary  inputs  and  support  for  the  formulation  of  the  proposed 
periodic plan, particularly with respect to infrastructure development.  
(vii)  In  collaboration  with  other  infrastructure  sector  experts  engaged  by  the  NPC, 
prepare  infrastructure-related  sections  of  the  proposed  periodic  plan  in  close 
consultation with the technical committee and other relevant stakeholders.   
(viii)  Undertake other tasks identified by the EA and ADB.  
 
2.  Social Sector Development Expert (national, 3 person-months) 
 
a.  Basic Qualifications 
 
(i)  A master's degree in social sciences 
(ii)  Work experience relevant to the tasks described below, preferably in other countries 
besides Nepal.  
(iii)  At least 10 years' overall work experience.  
 
b.  Tasks to be Performed 
 
(i)  Work closely with the technical committee constituted by NPC for formulating the 
social development (health, education and water supply and sanitation) component 
of the proposed periodic plan, and engage in the plan preparation process. 
(ii)  Work in accordance with the guidance and direction of the steering committee 
formed in the NPC for formulation of the periodic plan. 
(iii)  Under  the  guidance  of  the  social  development  technical  committee  and  in 
collaboration with other social sector experts engaged by the NPC (who will also be 
supervised  by  the  technical  committee),  assess  the  progress  of  infrastructure 
development vis-à-vis that envisaged in Three-Year Interim Plan. 
(iv)  Coordinate and undertake activities as required for wide stakeholder consultations, 
including civil society, political leaders, the private sector, and development partners. 
(v)  Facilitate preparatory work and workshops for the formulation of the periodic plan. 
(vi)  Provide  inputs  and  support  for  the  formulation  of  the  proposed  periodic  plan, 
particularly with respect to social development.   
(vii)  In  collaboration  with  other  infrastructure  sector  experts  engaged  by  the  NPC, 
prepare  parts  of  the  proposed  periodic  plan  related  to  social  sectors,  in  close 
consultation with the technical committee and other relevant stakeholders.   
(viii)  Undertake other tasks identified by the EA and ADB. 
 
3.  Local Development and Inclusion Expert (national, 3 person-months) 
 
a.  Basic Qualifications 
 
(i)  A master's degree in social sciences

14   Appendix 3   
 
(ii)  Work experience relevant to the tasks described below, preferably in other countries 
besides Nepal.  
(iii)  At least 10 years' overall work experience. 
 
b.  Tasks to be Performed 
 
(i)  Work closely with the technical committee constituted by the NPC for mainstreaming 
local  and  inclusive  development  processes  in  the  proposed  periodic  plan,  and 
engage in the plan preparation process. 
(ii)  Work under the guidance and direction of the steering committee formed in the NPC 
for formulating the periodic plan. 
(iii)  Assess  progress  in  promoting  local  and  inclusive  development  vis-à-vis  that 
envisaged in the Three-Year Interim Plan. 
(iv)  Coordinate and undertake activities required for wide stakeholder consultations, 
including civil society, political leaders, the private sector, and development partners. 
(v)  Facilitate preparatory work and workshops for the formulation of the periodic plan. 
(vi)  Provide inputs and support for formulation of the proposed periodic plan, particularly 
with respect to promoting local and inclusive development under the new periodic 
plan.   
(vii)  Prepare local and inclusive development sections of the proposed periodic plan in 
close consultation with the technical committee and other relevant stakeholders.   
(viii)  Undertake other tasks identified by the EA and ADB.
